results.title: A Chronic problem
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Scott, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Discussion in bioethics”.
One of a series of short, open-ended dramas designed to stimulate discussion of values and ethics in relation to modern medical technology. This film considers the chronic patient’s right to quality care, and the acutely ill patient’s right to a hospital bed. Jean is suffering from multiple sclerosis and is almost completely paralyzed. It seems that the only ones who care about her are the nurses. With the arrival of a patient in need of an operation, it becomes apparent that chronic patients have little priority.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cynthia Scott, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Vicky
results.creator_credit: Elsa Bolam, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
One of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults about teenage alienation. An unhappy suburban teenager whose affluent parents don’t get along, Vicki turns to an older man and a life of crime. Scenes in Vicky’s home clearly show the lack of communication between her parents, and between them and the girl.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elsa Bolam, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Robert
results.creator_credit: Cedric Smith, Wolf Koenig, Signe Johansson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Robert tells of the identity crisis of a fifteen-year-old whose father walked out years earlier. Already overwhelmed by problems at school, despair at the situation of the world, and his awkwardness with girls, Robert suddenly discovers that his mother has a serious boyfriend. One of a series of six short dramatic discussion starters for adolescents and adults on the subject of teenage alienation.

results.title: Mark and Donny
results.creator_credit: Pedro Gandol, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Part of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults about teenage alienation. Having been caught in a stolen car, Mark and Donny are seen being interviewed by the arresting officer, who is trying to ascertain responsibility. Mark’s mother promises to get him a lawyer and helps him shift the blame onto Donny. The policeman, meanwhile, has probed Donny’s reluctance to return home and discovered that the boy’s father abuses him.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pedro Gandol, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Jenny
results.creator_credit: Patricia Phillips, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Part of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults on teenage alienation, Jenny is the story of a seemingly tough seventeen-year-old who is arrested for trafficking drugs. Jenny’s story emerges as she is interviewed by a skilful social worker. Her unemployed, alcoholic father has been sexually abusing her, and is now turning his attention to her weaker, younger sister as well.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Phillips, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Alex
results.creator_credit: Brian Dooley, Wolf Koenig, Erna Buffie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
A teenager attempts to cope after his parents have separated. His working mother is rarely at home when Alex is. Although his father seems inaccessible, Alex boasts to his friends about their closeness. Amid unbearable emotional confusion, Alex grabs a woman’s purse and is caught. One of a series of six short dramatic discussion starters for adolescents and adults on the subject of teenage alineation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Dooley, Wolf Koenig, Erna Buffie and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Romans in Britain
results.brief_description: Three part series covering the centuries beginning and ending the Roman occupation of early Britain. The series traces the social, political and cultural impact of the Roman Empire on early Britain and the future of the country and investigates various historical landmarks and events that signal the significance of the Roman presence and influence. Other subjects discussed include culinary, architectural, religious and community planning traditions of Roman Britain, all illustrated through interviews with historians, archaeologists and re-enactment troups as well as investigation of artifacts and characteristics and representations of this period in contemporary England. “Roman’s in Britain” is a comprehensive investigation of the history of Rome and of Britain, and their mutually influential position in classical history.

group_works.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire

results.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The third program in the “Roman’s in Britain” series which discusses the history of one of the most famous landmarks of Roman Britain, Hadrian’s Wall. Through interviews with historians, archaeologists and museum curators and a discussion of artifacts and construction patterns present at the site, this episode explores the various theories about who built the wall, its purpose for the Roman Empire, and the impact it had on early Britain. A commentary on the gradual downfall of the Romans in Britain and their remaining legacy in a variety of forms in the country concludes the program.

group_siblings.title: Roman fact, Roman fable
group_siblings.creator_credit: Paul Manners and BBC-TV

results.title: Coming of age
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The second program in the Roman’s in Britain series which discusses the progression of the Roman rule over Britain over 4 centuries. It focuses on the history of the development of cities in Britain under the Roman Empire and their development of the notion of the country being a unified entity, a province governed from the centre rather than being separately managed tribal lands. This was symbolised most strikingly by the Roman’s establishment of the port town of London as a capital city and the legacy of 400 years worth of road construction across the country for ease of trade and travel between districts. The program also looks at the influence of the Roman empire over food preparation, the establishment of bath houses, architectural traditions, dynamics of the marketplace and the establishment of industrial complexes in early Britain. In the process the merging of the Celtic cultural landscape with that of Rome is examined, with discussion of the acknowledgement of the different cultures within the constructions of the Roman Empire in Britain as each country became a visible part of the other.
